    HCI in the 1970s

    ì˜ˆì „ì—ëŠ” ìƒì‚°ì„±ì´ ë” ê°•ì¡°ë˜ë˜ ì‹œê¸°

    ê·¸ ë‹¹ì‹œ ê°œë°œì€ waterfall ë°©ì‹ ì‚¬ìš©

    • ìœ ì € - ê·¹ë‹¨ì ì¸ ì´ë¶„ë²•

    HCI in the 1980s

    • ê²°ê³¼ë¥¼ ë³´ê³  í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ì•„ë‹ˆë¼ ì„¤ê³„ë¥¼ í•œë‹¤ìŒì— ìœ ì €ì—ê²Œ í™•ì¸
    • ì„¤ê³„ ëê¹Œì§€ ê°€ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ì•„ë‹ˆë¼ ì¤‘ê°„ ë‹¨ê³„ì—ì„œ ìœ ì €ì™€ì˜ interactionì„ í†µí•´ ìˆ˜ì •ì— ìˆ˜ì •ì„ ê±°ì¹¨
      • prototyping, mock-upsì˜ ì¤‘ìš”ì„±
      • formative evaluation
        • thinking aloud: ì‹œì œí’ˆì„ ìœ ì €ì—ê²Œ ì¨ë³´ë¼ê³  í•˜ê³  ê·¸ ë•Œ ìƒê°ë‚˜ëŠ” ëª¨ë“  ê²ƒì„ ë§í•˜ê¸°ë¥¼ ìš”êµ¬ í›„ ëª¨ë“  ì˜ê²¬ì„ ì·¨í•© ë° íŒŒì•…
        • ì¤‘ê°„ í‰ê°€ì˜ ë°©ë²•ë¡ ì´ ìƒê¸°ê¸° ì‹œì‘
    • Models and theory (vs. guidelines)
      • the model human processor
        • Fittsâ€™s Law: ì‚¬ëŒì´ ì•„ì´ì½˜ì„ í´ë¦­í•˜ëŠ” ë° ê±¸ë¦¬ëŠ” ì‹œê°„ì´ë‚˜ ë°°ì¹˜ë¥¼ íš¨ê³¼ì ìœ¼ë¡œ í•˜ê²Œë” ìˆ˜ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ ê·œì •í•´ ë†“ì€ ê²ƒ
        • GOMS: ì‚¬ëŒì´ ë©”ë‰´ë¥¼ ë³´ê³  ì–´ë–¤ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ ì›€ì§ì´ëŠ”ì§€ ëª¨ë¸ë§ í•œ ê²ƒ, operationì„ ì–´ë–»ê²Œ í•  ì§€ ëª¨ë¸ë§
      • mapping models: syntactic-semantic consistency
        • syntax: íœ´ì§€í†µì— íŒŒì¼ì„ ë²„ë¦°ë‹¤
        • semantic: ë²„ë¦¬ëŠ” ê±¸ íœ´ì§€í†µìœ¼ë¡œ ë§Œë“¦ìœ¼ë¡œì¨ ì˜ë¯¸ë¥¼ ì•Œê²Œë”í•˜ëŠ”.(ì˜ë¯¸ê°€ í†µí•˜ê²Œ)
      • the active user: prior knowledge, problem solving, and error as primary resources
        • ì´ë¯¸ ì´ì „ì— ì¢€ ì¨ ë³¸ ì‚¬ëŒë“¤(ì´ì „ ì§€ì‹ì„ ê°€ì§„ ì‚¬ëŒ)


    HCI in the 1990s

    • UE (usability engineering) is multifaceted, qualitative, field-oriented
      • ì–´ë””ì—ì„œ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ì§€ ê³ ë ¤í•˜ê¸° ì‹œì‘
      • participatory design, contextual design(ë§¥ë½ì„ ê³ ë ¤í•œ ë””ìì¸), ethnographicallyinformed design(ì–´ëŠ ë‚˜ë¼ ì‚¬ëŒì´ ì“¸ ê²ƒì¸ì§€, ì–´ë–¤ ë¬¸í™”ë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ ì‚¬ëŒì´ ì“¸ ê²ƒì¸ì§€ë¥¼ ê³ ë ¤í•œ ë””ìì¸)
      • drives/integrates system development lifecycle
        • version2, version3, â€¦.
    • Conceptual frameworks beyond user models
      • activity theory, ethnomethodology(ë¯¼ì¡±ì ì¸), distributed cognition(ê°œì¸ì´ ì•„ë‹Œ ì‚¬íšŒê°€ ê°–ê³  ìˆëŠ” ì˜ì‹, ì˜í–¥), grounded theory, design rationale
      • But diminishing role in mainstream discourse (ë¬¼ë¡  mainstreamê³¼ ë©€ì–´ì§€ê¸° ì‹œì‘)
        • ê¸°ìˆ ë“¤ì´ ë„ˆë¬´ integrated ë˜ì–´ ìˆì–´ì„œ ì‹ ê²½ ì“°ì§€ ì•Šì•„ë„ë  ì •ë„ê°€ ë¨
    • User interface technology too well integrated!


    Context of HCI: Changes in Computer Use

    • 1960â€™s - Professional programmers, software psychology
      • ì „ë¬¸ì„±ì´ ì§™ìŒ
    • 1970â€™s - Business professionals, mainframes, command-line
      • ë¹„ì§€ë‹ˆìŠ¤ì—ì„œ ì‚¬ìš©ë˜ê¸° ì‹œì‘, êµ‰ì¥íˆ í° mainframeê³¼ ê°™ì€ ê²ƒì´ íšŒì‚¬ì—ì„œ ì‚¬ìš©ë˜ê¸° ì‹œì‘
    • 1980â€™s - Large, diverse user groups, the computer for the rest of us
      • ì»´í“¨í„°ì˜ ë³´í¸í™”
    • 1990â€™s - World Wide Web and more, information access & overload
    • 2000+ - Ubiquitous computing, diversity in task, device, â€¦


    Historical basis of HCI

    • University Research
    • Corporate Research
    • Commercial Products

    ë§ˆìš°ìŠ¤ ì—°êµ¬ê°€ ëŠê¸´ ê²ƒì´ ë§ˆìš°ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ì—°êµ¬í•˜ì§€ ì•ŠëŠ”ë‹¤ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ì•„ë‹ˆë¼ ë§ˆìš°ìŠ¤ë¼ëŠ” ê°œë…ìœ¼ë¡œì„œ ì¶”ê°€ì ì¸ integrationì´ ê±°ì˜ ëë‚œ ê²ƒ


    Basic Interaction (1)

    • Graphical Objects
      • 1963 (MIT)
        • Graphical Objects manipulated by a pointing device (light pen)
        • Objects could be selected, moved, resized, etc.
      • 1966 (Imperial College, London)
        • Icons, Gesture Recognition, Dynamic Menus, etc.
      • 1970 (XEROX Palo Alto Research Center)
        • XEROX: ë³µì‚¬ê¸°ë¡œ ìœ ëª…í•œ íšŒì‚¬, ë³µì‚¬í•œë‹¤ëŠ” ëœ»ì´ê¸°ë„ í•¨.
        • Object selection and manipulation
        • WYSIWYG
          • What You See What You Get


    Basic Interaction (2)

    • Mouse
      • 1965 (Stanford Research Lab [SRI])
        • Created to be a cheap replacement for light pens
        • light penì´ ë¹„ìŒˆ -> ì‹¼ ê±¸ë¡œ ë°”ê¾¸ê³ ì í–ˆë˜ ê²ƒì´ mouse
      • 1970
        • Adopted at Xerox PARC
      • First appeared commercially as part of
        • The Xerox Star (1981),
        • The Apple Lisa (1982),
        • The Apple Macintosh (1984).


    Basic Interaction (3)

    • Windows
      • 1968 (Stanford Research Lab [SRI])
      • 1969 - 1974 (Xerox PARC)
        • Smalltalk System
      • 1974 (MIT)
        • EMACS Text Editor - ìš°ë¦¬ê°€ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒê³¼ ê±°ì˜ ë¹„ìŠ·í•œ ì—ë””í„°
      • 1981 (Xerox PARC)
        • The Cedar Window Manager
      • 1981 Xerox Star
      • 1982 Apple Lisa
      • 1983 (Carnegie Mellon University funded by IBM))
        • Andrew window manager
      • 1984 Apple Macintosh
        • í›¨ì”¬ ë” ìì—°ìŠ¤ëŸ½ê²Œ
      • The early versions of the Star and Microsoft Windows were tiled, but eventually they supported overlapping windows like the Lisa and Macintosh.


    Applications (1)

    • Drawing programs
      • uses a mouse for graphics (1965)
      • uses a tablet (1971)
      • handling of lines and curves (1975)
    • Text Editing
      • first word processor with automatic word wrap, search & replace, user-definable macros, scrolling text, & commands to move, copy, and delete characters, words, or blocks of text (1962)
      • screen editing & formatting of arbitrary-sized strings with a lightpen (1967)
      • mouse-based editing (1968)
      • first WYSIWYG editor-formatter (1974)


    Applications (2)

    • Spreadsheets
      • Initial spreadsheet was VisiCalc (1977-8) for the Apple II
    • HyperText
      • The idea where documents are linked to related documents (1945)
      • Ted Nelson coined the term â€œhypertextâ€ (1965)
      • NLS system was one of the first on-line journals, and it included full linking of articles (1970)
        • Online System - NLS
      • HyperCard from Apple (1988) significantly helped to bring the idea to a wide audience
      • Tim Berners-Lee used the hypertext idea to create the World Wide Web in 1990 at the government-funded European Particle Physics Laboratory (CERN)
        • ì…ì ê°€ì†ê¸°
      • Mosaic, the first popular hypertext browser for the World-Wide Web, released in 1993
        • ì›¹ ë¸Œë¼ìš°ì €


    Applications (3)

    • Computer Aided Design (CAD)
      • first CAD systems similar to drawing programs (1963)
      • pioneering work on interactive 3D CAD system (1963)
        • ì²˜ìŒ ëª©ì ì´ ë°°ë‚˜ ì´ëŸ° ê²ƒë“¤ì„ ìœ„í•œ ê²ƒì´ì—ˆê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— 3Dë¡œ ì‹œì‘
      • first CAD/CAM (manufacture) system in industry was probably General Motorâ€™s DAC-1 (about 1963)
    • Video Games
      • first graphical video game was probably SpaceWar (1962)
      • the first computer joysticks (1962)
      • early computer adventure game was created (1966)
      • first popular commercial game was Pong (about 1976).


    Up & Coming Areas (1)

    • Gesture Recognition
      • first pen-based input device used light-pen gestures (1963)
      • first trainable gesture recognizer (1964)
      • a gesture-based text editor using proof-reading symbols (1969)
      • gesture recognition has been used in commercial CAD systems since the 1970s
      • came to universal notice with the Apple Newton (1992)
    • Multimedia
      • ì»´í“¨í„°ì— ë“±ì¥í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì„ ëª¨ë‘ í•œêº¼ë²ˆì— ë“±ì¥í† ë¡ í•˜ëŠ”(í…ìŠ¤íŠ¸, ê·¸ë˜í”½, ìŠ¤í”¼ì¹˜, â€¦)
      • multiple windows with integrated text and graphics (1968)
      • Interactive Graphical Documents project was the first hypermedia system which used raster graphics and text (1979- 1983)
      • Diamond project explored combining multimedia (text, spreadsheets, graphics, speech) (1982)


    Up & Coming Areas (2)

    • 3-D
      • first system 3-D CAD system (1963)
      • first interactive 3-D system used for molecular modelling (1966)
      • the late 60â€™s and early 70â€™s saw the flowering of 3D raster graphics funded by the government
      • the military-industrial flight simulation work of the 60â€™s - 70â€™s led the way to making 3-D real-time
    • Virtual Reality
      • ì´ ë•Œ ë‹¹ì‹œì— VR ì¥ë¹„ê°€ ATMë³´ë‹¤ í° ì •ë„ì˜€ìŒ
      • original work on VR funded by Air Force (1965-1968)
      • study of force feedback, early research on head-mounted displays and on the DataGlove (1971)


    Up & Coming Areas (2)

    • Computer Supported Cooperative Work
      • remote participation of multiple people at various sites (1968)
      • Electronic mail, still the most widespread multi-user software, was enabled by the ARPAnet (1969)
      • and by the Ethernet from Xerox PARC (1973)
      • an early computer conferencing system (1975)
    • Natural language and speech
      • Speech synthesis
      • Speech recognition


    HCI as a business necessity

    • Can the users be ignored? (Linux, Windows,â€¦)
    • NO
      • HCI + Usability engineering are a crucial business necessity
        • í”¼ì³í°ë§Œ í•´ë„ ë˜ëŠ” ê¸°ëŠ¥ì´ ê½¤ ìˆì—ˆëŠ”ë° ì¸í„°í˜ì´ìŠ¤ í•˜ë‚˜ë§Œ ë°”ê¾¸ì—ˆë”ë‹ˆ(ìŠ¤ë§ˆíŠ¸í°) êµ‰ì¥í•œ í˜ì‹ ì„ ë¶ˆëŸ¬ì˜´
      • Good Interface & Interaction Design should not be added after system is built
      • Supporting users is an integral part of the design. To do this one must consider â€¦
        • International Standards in HCI and Ergonomics
        • User population is growing (size, diversity, etc.)
        • Expanding awareness amongst users of what can be achieved


    Case Study (1)

    • A mechanical syringe was once being developed. An input device had to be created in order to enter the injected dose


    Case Study (2)

    • A prototype was developed by the manufacturing company and demonstrated to the hospital staff. Happily they quickly noticed the potentially fatal flaw in its interface.

    í‚¤ë¥¼ ì˜ëª»ëˆ„ë¥´ë©´ ë§í•œë‹¤ëŠ” ì¸í„°í˜ì´ìŠ¤


    Case Study (3)

    • The doses were entered by a numeric keypad: an accidental keypress and the dose could be out by a factor of 10! The production version had individual increment/decrement buttons for each digit

    ë‹¨ìˆœíˆ í¸í•˜ê³  ë©‹ì§„ ë””ìì¸ë§Œì´ HCIì—ì„œ ìƒê°í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ì•„ë‹ˆë¼ ì•ˆì „ì„±, í¸ì˜ì„± ê°„ì˜ tradeoffë¥¼ ìƒê°í•´ ë´ì„œ ìµœì ì˜ ì¸í„°í˜ì´ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ê³ ë ¤í•´ ë‚´ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ë‹¤.


    Safety-critical systems

    • Poor designs
      • Very common in
        • Safety
        • Life-critical
      • Which all depend on computer-control
      • We need to understand why these happen?
        • Disasters
        • Accidents
        • Frustrations


    â€˜User Hostileâ€™ example

    • Poor HCI can lead to User Hostile systems rather than User Friendly ones â€¦
      • John has a stereo system with a matched set of components made by the same manufacturer: a receiver, a CD player, and a cassette deck, stacked in that order. They all have the on/off button on the left side. Every time John goes to turn off all three components, he presses the top left button on the receiver, which turns it off; then he presses the top left button on the CD player, which turns it off; then, naturally, he presses the top left button on the cassette deck â€“ which pops open the cassette door.
    • ì´ëŸ° ì¼ì´ ë°œìƒí•˜ëŠ” ì´ìœ ëŠ” ì•°í”„ë¥¼ ë§Œë“œëŠ” íŒ€ê³¼ ì¹´ì„¸íŠ¸ë¥¼ ë§Œë“œëŠ” íŒ€ì´ ë‹¤ë¥´ë‹¤.(íšŒì‚¬ëŠ” ê°™ë”ë¼ë„)
    • stereo ì‹œìŠ¤í…œì´ ìˆì–´ì•¼ ë˜ëŠ” ì´ìœ ëŠ” ì»¤ë‹¤ë€ ìŠ¤í”¼ì»¤ë¥¼ í•¸ë“¤ë§ í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´ì„œ ë‚˜ì˜¨ ê²ƒì´ë‹¤.(í•¸ë“œí° x)


    Itâ€™s obvious

    • It seems â€œobviousâ€ that the manufacturer could have improved the interface
      • putting all three buttons in the same location
    • But it clearly wasnâ€™t obvious to the systemâ€™s designers!!
    • Most actions used to accomplish tasks with an interface are quite obvious to people who know them, including, of course, the software designer. But the actions are often not obvious to the first-time user.


    Another exampleâ€¦

    • Imagine a first-time user of a computer
      • he has been shown how to login to the system
      • has done some work
      • is now finished with the computer for the day
    • Experienced computer users will find it obvious that a logout command is needed.
    • But it may not occur to first-time users that a special action is required to end the session.
      • People donâ€™t â€œlog outâ€ of typewriters or televisions or video games, so why should they log out of computers?
    • Learning to predict problems like these by taking the userâ€™s point of view is a skill that requires practice.
      • ì´ëŸ° ê²ƒë“¤ì€ ì—°ìŠµì„ ìš”êµ¬í•˜ëŠ” ìŠ¤í‚¬ì´ì–ì•„?!
    • ì—‘ì…€ íŒŒì¼ì„ xë¥¼ ëˆŒëŸ¬ ê»ëŠ”ë° ì €ì¥ ì—¬ë¶€ë¥¼ ë¬»ëŠ” íŒì—…ì°½ì´ ì—†ë‹¤ë©´ UXëŠ” ìµœì•…ì¼ ê²ƒì´ë‹¤.

    ì²˜ìŒ ì“°ëŠ” ìœ ì €ë„ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë„ë¡ ìœ ë„í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ë””ìì¸ì´ ì¢‹ì€ ë””ìì¸ì´ë‹¤.

    ë§Œì•½ ì˜ˆìƒì¹˜ ëª»í•œ ì¼ë¡œ ì–´ë–¤ ì‚¬ìš©ìì—ê²ŒëŠ” í° ì¼ì´ ë²Œì–´ì§„ë‹¤ë©´ ê·¸ ì‚¬ìš©ìëŠ” ë‹¤ì‹œëŠ” ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì§€ ì•Šì„ ê²ƒì´ë‹¤.
